title: Contract Management After Award — From Kick-off to Closeout
description: Comprehensive guidance for contract management post-award — governance, reporting, change control, payments and dispute avoidance tailored for Qatar projects.
content:
Purpose & Scope

Winning the tender is only the start. Effective contract management ensures delivery, reduces disputes and protects both parties. This article covers the essential steps to manage awarded contracts successfully.

Immediate Post-Award Tasks

  1. Award Letter & Contract Signing

    Issue a formal award letter, attach the final contract, and collect signed copies. Use an acknowledgement form to capture any immediate clarifications.

  2. Assign Governance

    Define the project governance: project manager, commercial lead, and steering committee. Provide contact details and escalation paths.

  3. Kick-off Meeting

    Hold a kick-off within 7–10 days of award. Share a draft delivery schedule, communication plan, risk register, and initial resource plan.

Planning & Baseline

Agree on a baseline plan with milestones and acceptance criteria. The baseline is the reference for progress tracking and change requests. Ensure both parties sign off on milestone definitions.

Change Control & Variations

Define a written change control process: submit request → impact assessment (time & cost) → approval → documentation and update baseline. Track all change requests in a register with unique IDs and dates.

Performance Monitoring & Reporting

Establish a reporting cadence (weekly operational reports and monthly executive dashboards). Include metrics such as:

  • Schedule performance (milestone completion %)
  • Earned value indicators (if applicable)
  • Quality non-conformance incidents
  • Open change requests
  • Financial status vs baseline (invoiced vs planned)

Payments & Invoicing

Link invoices to milestone or deliverable acceptance. Use a simple invoice checklist: invoice number, purchase order reference, description matched to milestone, instrument references for retention claims, and bank details. Avoid vague invoices that delay payments.

Risk Management

Maintain a live risk register with owners, likelihood, impact, and mitigation steps. Review risks in weekly operational meetings and escalate the top 5 risks to the steering committee monthly.

Quality & Acceptance

Define acceptance tests and deliverable quality checks. Use sign-off templates that record the person responsible, test evidence, and any corrective actions. Keep all acceptance records centralized on the platform for audit trails.

Stakeholder Communication

Have a RACI for stakeholder communications. Agree on who communicates what to whom (client, subcontractors, regulators). Use short status emails with key actions and decisions to maintain a clean record.

Dispute Prevention & Resolution

Most disputes arise from poor documentation or unmanaged variations. Minimize risk by documenting decisions, maintaining a change log and agreeing on quick, pragmatic resolution steps in the contract (initial negotiation → mediation → arbitration as last resort).

Project Closeout

  1. Final Acceptance: complete outstanding items and obtain a final acceptance certificate.
  2. Financial Close: settle retention, final payments, and release performance guarantees as per the contract.
  3. Knowledge Transfer: hand over documentation, training material and maintenance schedules.
  4. Lessons Learned: conduct a lessons-learned workshop and store the findings for future procurements.

Templates & Checklists

Below are short templates you can copy:

Sample Kick-off Agenda

  • Introductions & roles
  • Scope review
  • Baseline schedule
  • Reporting cadence
  • Risk register review
  • Immediate next steps

Change Request Register Columns

  • CR ID
  • Date Submitted
  • Requested By
  • Description
  • Impact (Time & Cost)
  • Status
  • Approval Date

Closing Remarks

Good contract management converts awards into value. Invest time early in governance, baseline planning and simple, enforceable change controls — it pays back through fewer disputes, better timelines and higher client satisfaction.
